Name: Fasting Glucose
Notes: Normal: 70-100 mg/dL. Optimal: 75-90 mg/dL.

Name: Cellular Glucose
Notes: Intracellular glucose for glycolysis.

Name: ATP (Cytosolic)
Notes: High energy charge essential for cellular function.

Name: ADP (Cytosolic)
Notes: Substrate for ATP synthesis. ATP/ADP ratio should be >5.

Name: NAD+ (Mitochondrial)
Notes: Declines with age. Optimal levels mimic healthy 20-year-old.

Name: NADH (Mitochondrial)
Notes: NAD+/NADH ratio should be ~3-10 in mitochondria.

Name: NAD+ (Cytosolic)
Notes: Cytosolic NAD+ for SIRT1 activity.

Name: S-Adenosylmethionine
Notes: Primary methyl donor. Critical for epigenetics.

Name: S-Adenosylhomocysteine
Notes: SAM/SAH ratio should be >4 for optimal methylation.

Name: Homocysteine
Notes: Lower is better. Elevated = cardiovascular risk.

Name: Methionine
Notes: Essential amino acid for methylation cycle.

Name: 5-MTHF (Methylfolate)
Notes: Active folate form. MTHFR SNPs affect levels.

Name: Glutathione (Reduced)
Notes: Primary antioxidant. Higher is better for longevity.

Name: Glutathione (Oxidized)
Notes: GSH/GSSG ratio should be >10 for redox balance.

Name: Reactive Oxygen Species
Notes: Some ROS needed for signaling, excess causes damage.

Name: Insulin
Notes: Fasting: 2-12 uU/mL. Lower is better for longevity.

Name: Cortisol
Notes: Varies by time of day. Peak in morning.

Name: Pyruvate
Notes: Glycolysis endpoint. Enters Krebs as acetyl-CoA.

Name: Acetyl-CoA
Notes: Central metabolic hub. Enters Krebs cycle.

Name: Citrate
Notes: Krebs cycle intermediate. Inhibits PFK when high.

Name: Alpha-Ketoglutarate
Notes: Links Krebs to amino acid metabolism.

Name: Succinate
Notes: Krebs intermediate. Feeds Complex II.

Name: Fumarate
Notes: Links urea cycle to Krebs cycle.

Name: Malate
Notes: Krebs intermediate. Part of malate-aspartate shuttle.

Name: Oxaloacetate
Notes: Krebs acceptor molecule. Links to gluconeogenesis.

Name: Free Fatty Acids
Notes: Elevated in fasting/diabetes. Energy source.

Name: Blood Urea Nitrogen
Notes: 7-20 mg/dL normal. Reflects protein metabolism.

Name: Ammonia
Notes: Toxic at high levels. Converted to urea.

Name: Arginine
Notes: NO precursor. Urea cycle intermediate.

Name: Citrulline
Notes: Urea cycle intermediate. Marker of gut health.

Name: Ornithine
Notes: Urea cycle carrier. Supports polyamine synthesis.

Name: Glutamate
Notes: Main excitatory neurotransmitter. Nitrogen carrier.

Name: Aspartate
Notes: Urea cycle input. Neurotransmitter.

Name: Cysteine
Notes: Rate-limiting for glutathione synthesis.

Name: NMN
Notes: NAD+ precursor. Target for longevity interventions.

Name: Nicotinamide
Notes: Vitamin B3 form. Recycled to NAD+.

Name: AMP
Notes: Energy sensor. Activates AMPK when elevated.

Name: AMPK (Active)
Notes: Energy sensor. Higher = more repair/autophagy.

Name: mTOR (Active)
Notes: Growth signal. Lower may improve longevity.

Name: NF-kB (Active)
Notes: Inflammation marker. Lower is better.

Name: Carnitine
Notes: Required for fat transport into mitochondria.

Name: Coenzyme A
Notes: Acyl group carrier. Essential for metabolism.

Name: FAD
Notes: Riboflavin coenzyme. Electron carrier.

Name: FADH2
Notes: Reduced FAD. Feeds Complex II for ATP.
